en: A lot has been happening, and there’s a lot to catch up on, the most pressing of which is another fight with Sandra. You always feel sick to your stomach when you and Sandra have fought, and today is no different.
zh: 這些天發生了很多事情，還有很多事情需要去做，最讓你記掛的是你和桑德拉又大吵一架。

en: Strike that—today you actually feel worse. It was a real doozy.
zh: 別說不適了，今天你真的感覺更糟，簡直疼痛難忍。

en: Things are a little more stressful now that the wedding has been bumped up—that was something decided a few days ago, but first you need to be updated on today.
zh: 婚禮已經迫在眉睫了，事情排山倒海地湧來。婚期是幾天前就定好了的，但今天還需要確認最新日期。

en: This is, remember, a journal—it maps the journey. It’s not a diary— you’re not going to add something every day just because it’s another day.
zh: 記住了，這隻是隨想錄，而不是你的日程清單，它如實地記錄了你的心路歷程，但無須你每天筆耕不輟。

en: Otherwise it’d be Day fourteen, ate breakfast, went for a walk, and read the newspaper at the kitchen table.
zh: 否則，今天應該會這樣寫：今天是第十四天，吃早飯，散步，在餐桌旁讀報紙。

en: Over to you, Henry. It was a Tuesday when Sandra borrowed the diary.
zh: 今天是星期二，桑德拉借走了日記。

en: A Tuesday like any other for most people, but not for Sandra—this was her second Tuesday since learning her husband was leaving her, and she was going to spend it reading his inner thoughts.
zh: 對很多人來說，這是個再平常不過的星期二，但對桑德拉來說，這是她知道丈夫即將離開她后的第二個星期二，她要走進他真正的內心世界。

en: He was scared, she was pretty sure of that—hell, she was scared.
zh: 他嚇壞了，她也知道自己會嚇壞的。

en: By the end of next year she would be alone, perhaps even by the end of this one.
zh: 到明年年底，或者今年年底，她將成為孤零零的一個人。

en: She couldn’t help it, but already she was thinking of what she would do—would she move on?
zh: 她無力阻止，但她已經想好要做什麼了，不過她會做嗎？

en: Would she meet somebody else and start a new life?
zh: 因為即便他還活著，也只剩一副皮囊了，靈魂早已遠去。她會不會遇到另一個男人，開始另一段新生活？

en: She didn’t know.
zh: 她不知道。

en: And what if she did start that new life, and in five years’ time there was a cure and Jerry became Jerry again?
zh: 萬一她真開始了新的生活，但五年後傑瑞痊癒了，他重新回到自己的軀殼裡了，她又該怎麼辦？

en: That was breakfast—not the healthiest, but she never had been the healthiest when it came to eating, which is why she hit the gym three days a week before work —four, if there was time—and time, she thought, was something she wouldn’t have much of while Jerry was sick.
zh: 不過說到吃的，她也不吃那些，所以上班之前她總會去一趟健身房，每周三天，要是有空就四天。不過自打傑瑞患病以來，她的生活就再也沒有「有空」一說了。

en: She would have to take time off work, which would be tough, as there were some cases ready to go to trial, but she would do it.
zh: 她還得請假，這很難，因為她還有些案子要上庭，但她還是得請。

en: She would do anything for Jerry. She was already taking time off to help Eva plan the wedding.
zh: 她甘願為傑瑞傾盡所有，其餘的時間就幫伊娃籌劃婚禮。

en: She carried the diary and her breakfast outside. She sat at the table on the deck and sipped her coffee and started to read.
zh: 她把日記和早餐拿到外面，坐在露台上的桌子旁一邊喝著咖啡一邊閱讀。

en: Day One, the opening words, and there was Jerry talking to himself, Jerry sounding just like . . . well, just like Jerry.
zh: 第一天是開場白，傑瑞在自言自語，看上去就像是……好吧，還是像傑瑞。

en: The neighbor’s cat had jumped the fence and was sitting on the edge of the deck, pausing from cleaning itself every now and then to stare at her.
zh: 一隻鄰居的貓躍過了柵欄，蹲在露台邊舔著自己的身體，時不時地停下來盯著她看。

en: “Just what the hell is this?”
zh: 「這是什麼鬼東西？」

en: she asked, waking him up.
zh: 她把他吵醒了。

en: “You’re reading my journal?”
zh: 「你偷看我的日記？」

en: “You asked me to.”
zh: 「你叫我看的。」

en: She paused for a moment, looking for the deception, but no, he wasn’t lying, he had woken with no memory of it.
zh: 她沉默了一會兒，看他是不是在撒謊，但並不是的，他看起來不像在撒謊，反倒是像醒來后什麼都不記得了。

en: “But what’s more important is that we have a gun in the house. How could you!
zh: 她說，忽然又想到為什麼來和他吵架，「但重點是我們家裡竟然有槍。

en: And you think that what, one day you may use it on yourself?”
zh: 你怎麼能這樣？你在想什麼？難道有一天你會把它用在自己身上？」

en: “You had no right to read any of it!”
zh: 「你沒有權利看我的日記！」

en: “I have every right because you’re my husband and I love you, and I hate that this thing is happening to you, but it is, and I need to know what’s going on in here so I can help you,” she said, and she tapped the side of her head, but really she should have been tapping the side of his.
zh: 「我有充分的權利看你的日記，因為你是我丈夫，我愛你，我不想看到這種事發生在你身上，但它還是發生了。我需要知道你這裏究竟在想什麼，這樣我才能幫你。」她說著，拍了拍自己的頭，但其實她應該拍他的頭，這讓她像個瘋婦一般。

en: “Doesn’t sound like it,” he said. “Sounds more like you’re spying on me.”
zh: 「說得好聽，」他說，「你只是想監視我。」

en: “I would never—”
zh: 「我從來沒有——」

en: “Get out,” he yelled, and threw the journal at her.
zh: 「滾！」他喊道，拿起日記本向她砸去，但他砸偏了，日記本砸在她身後的牆上。

en: It missed and hit the wall behind her. She had never seen him like that, and it frightened her. It worried her. She knew even before Jerry was diagnosed that no matter what the problem was, she would stay by his side.
zh: 她從未見過這樣的傑瑞，這讓她驚恐不安，但她知道，無論最後傑瑞被診斷出什麼，她都會矢志不渝地留在他身邊。

en: For always. That journal hitting the wall next to her—in that moment there was a flicker of doubt.
zh: 日記本砸在她身邊牆上的瞬間，她的心中閃過一絲疑惑。

en: She picked it up and ran out of the room.
zh: 她把日記本撿起來，跑出了房間。

en: By the time she got out to the deck, she was crying.
zh: 跑到露台上時，她哭了。

en: Twenty seconds later Jerry was behind her.
zh: 二十秒鐘后，傑瑞來到她身後，她轉身面對著他。

en: She turned towards him, but it wasn’t the Jerry from the bedroom, it was the Jerry she fell in love with, the one she met in university, the one who was in the Star Trek closet, the one whose side she would never leave.
zh: 他已經不是卧室里的傑瑞了，他是她深愛的傑瑞，是她在大學相識的傑瑞，是藏滿了一柜子《星際迷航》影碟的傑瑞，是她永遠不離不棄的傑瑞。

en: Beverly, the grief counselor, had warned them he could get like this. It was all part of the Alzheimer’s package.
zh: 那位憂傷的心理諮詢師貝弗莉曾警告過他們他會這樣，這隻是阿爾茨海默病的冰山一角。

en: It was going to take time to adapt, but adapt she would. For him. For herself. For Eva.
zh: 他們需要很久來適應，但她終會適應的，為了他，為了自己，也為了伊娃。

en: “I’m just so . . .
zh: 「我真是……糟透了。」

en: “It’s going to be okay,” she said, and they were words she’d heard herself using over the last few weeks, as if her saying them enough would make them come true.
zh: 「都會好的。」她說。過去的幾個星期她也常常聽自己這樣說過，好像說得越多就越會變成真的一樣。

en: “I want you to read the rest of the journal,” he said.
zh: 「你可以把日記讀完。」他說。

en: “Are you sure?”
zh: 「你確定嗎？」

en: “I’m sure.”
zh: 「我確定。」

en: He disappeared inside to make breakfast while she stayed on the deck.
zh: 他走進屋裡準備早飯，獨留她在露台上。

en: When she finished she went back inside and found him in the kitchen eating a piece of toast and staring out the window.
zh: 她讀完日記后回到屋裡，看見他在廚房裡嚼著一塊麵包，獃獃地凝視窗外。

en: “I want you to get rid of the gun,” she said, staying calm.
zh: 「我想讓你把槍處理掉。」她平靜地說。

en: He turned towards her. “I’m not going to kill myself.”
zh: 他轉向她：「我不會自殺的。」

en: “Jerry, please, I would feel better if it was out of the house.”
zh: 「求你了，傑瑞。如果把它處理掉，我會更安心一些。」

en: He nodded. He didn’t look like he was going to argue. “It’s under the desk in my office.”
zh: 他點了點頭，像是懶得再爭論了：「槍就在我寫作房的桌子底下。」

en: “I know. You mentioned it in the diary.”
zh: 「我知道，你在日記里提到過。」

en: “It’s a journal. Not a diary.”
zh: 「是隨想錄，不是日記。」

en: They walked together to the office, and she stood aside as he pushed the desk towards the window.
zh: 他們一起走到寫作房。她站在一邊，他把桌子朝窗戶那邊推了推，從辦公桌的抽屜里取出一把螺絲刀，用它把一塊鬆動的地板撬了起來。

en: “What do you mean gone?”
zh: 「什麼叫『不見了』？」

en: He pulled his arm back out. There was nothing in his hand.
zh: 他把手收了回來，手裡什麼也沒有。

en: “It was here, and it’s always here, but now it isn’t.”
zh: 「明明就在這裏，一直在這裏的，但是現在不見了。」

en: He looked rattled. “I don’t . . . I don’t know where it is,” he said.
zh: 他有些驚慌失措起來，「我不……我不知道它在哪裡了。」

en: It looked like Jerry from the bedroom might be on his way back.
zh: 他說，剛剛在卧室里的傑瑞好像又還魂了。

en: “Well it has to be somewhere,” she said.
zh: 「肯定在什麼地方。」她說。

en: “I know, goddamn it, I know!”
zh: 「我知道了，媽的，我知道了！」

en: “Well, check again.”
zh: 「好的，再看看。」

en: He checked again and got the same result.
zh: 他又檢查了一遍，仍是一無所獲。

en: “Where else would you hide it?”
zh: 「你還會藏在什麼地方？」

en: “Nowhere. This is the place.”
zh: 「沒有，就是這兒。」

en: “If this is the place then it would still be there,” she said, still sounding calm.
zh: 「如果就是這兒，那應該還在這兒。」

en: At least calmer than she felt. “When did you last see it?”
zh: 她仍舊波瀾不驚地說，至少她比自己想象的要更加平靜，「你最後一次看見它是什麼時候？」

en: “I don’t know.”
zh: 「我不知道。」

en: “Why did you even have one?”
zh: 「你為什麼有槍？」

en: she asked.
zh: 她問。

en: “For research.
zh: 「為了研究槍。

en: I wanted to know how it felt to fire one. I went to the range a few times.”
zh: 我想知道開槍是什麼感覺，我去過幾次山裡。」

en: “Without telling me.
zh: 「你沒有告訴過

en: Is there anything else you’re not telling me?”
zh: 我，你是不是還有別的什麼事瞞著我？」

en: “No.” “Then when was the last time you used it at the range?”
zh: 「你最後一次在山裡用它是什麼時候？」

en: “It was . . . I . . . I can’t remember.”
zh: 「是……我……我不記得了。」

en: “When was the last time you saw it?”
zh: 「你最後一次看到它是什麼時候？」

en: “I don’t know.”
zh: 「我不知道。」

en: “And you’re sure that’s where you keep it?”
zh: 「你確定把它放到這裏了嗎？」

en: she asked.
zh: 她問。

en: “Of course I’m sure.”
zh: 「我十分確定。」

en: “So where is it, then? Where in the hell is the gun?”
zh: 「那槍呢？

en: And . . . scene.
zh: 這就是……現場。

en: Thanks, Henry, for the recap.
zh: 謝謝你，亨利，謝謝你複述了現場。

en: Needless to say, you feel ashamed for yelling at Sandra, and embarrassed because you have no idea where the gun is.
zh: 不用說，你因為對桑德拉大喊大叫而愧疚不已，你因為連槍在哪裡都不知道而難堪。

en: It’s possible you never even bought one.
zh: 也可能你從來就沒買過什麼槍。

en: Actually, you know what? There’s a character in one of the books—he bought a gun and hid it beneath a loose floorboard in his office.
zh: 你知道嗎，其實是書中的角色買了一把槍，把它藏在辦公室里一塊鬆動的地板下。

en: He was planning a murder, he was the one who wanted to know how it felt, how it sounded.
zh: 他策劃了一場謀殺，想知道殺人是什麼感覺。這個想法聽起來怎麼樣？

en: Is it possible that’s what you’ve been thinking of? Yes. Absolutely.
zh: 很有可能你一直是這麼想的。

en: You found the loose floorboard when you moved into the house, and at the time thought it’d be a good place to hide a gun, so gave that to the character you were writing about at the time.
zh: 是的，絕對是的。當你搬進來時發現了那塊鬆動的地板，你覺得這是塊藏槍的好地方，所以就把這一想法賦予書中的角色了。

en: You thought it was you, but it wasn’t—it was just one of those people living in your head!
zh: 你以為藏槍的是你，但其實不是的，只是你腦海中虛構出來的人物把槍藏了起來！

en: Sandra will be relieved when you tell her.
zh: 要是你告訴桑德拉，她肯定會釋然的。

en: But you—you’re terrified. To have made a mistake like that . . . what does that mean for your future?
zh: 但是你呢——你驚懼不安：犯了這樣的錯誤……這對你的未來意味著什麼？

en: All that stuff—that was today.
zh: 這就是今天發生的一切了。

en: There’s no time now to update you on the other night when Eva came over, as it’s date night tonight and you’re heading out soon with Sandra.
zh: 沒有時間寫伊娃過來的那個晚上了，今晚是約會之夜，你和桑德拉馬上就要出門了。

en: You’re off to dinner, then off to see a movie that one of your author buddies wrote.
zh: 你們會出去吃頓飯，然後看部電影，電影的劇本是你的一個作家哥們兒寫的。

en: The blanks will be filled in soon, but basically Eva and Rick have set an earlier date for the wedding to make sure you’re able to participate.
zh: 上面的空白頁會補上的。伊娃和瑞克已經將婚禮提前了，這樣確保你能參加。

en: Good news—Sandra has forgiven you for the fight and will forgive you even more when you’re at dinner and you tell her there’s no gun in the house.
zh: 好消息：關於吵架的事，桑德拉原諒了你。吃晚餐時，你告訴她家裡已經沒有槍了，她也原諒了你。

en: You and me, buddy, we have a lot to make up for after our fight with her, and a lot to make up for for the days that are coming.
zh: 老兄，你和我，我們倆都要在跟她大吵一架后彌補她，也要為接下來的日子彌補她。

en: Also, her birthday is coming up next month—she’s going to be joining you at forty-nine.
zh: 另外，下個月就是她生日了，這是她四十九歲的生日，她會和你一起度過。

en: You’ll get her something special.
zh: 你會送給她一份特別的禮物。

en: Good news—if you can’t remember how your books go, you can read them as if they’re new.
zh: 好消息：要是你不記得自己的書是怎樣寫的了，你可以開始閱讀它們，權當它們是新書。

en: It would be great if you could tap the dementia patient market—they buy your books, forget they’ve read them, and buy them again.
zh: 若是能開拓患有老年痴呆症的讀者市場，其實也挺好的——讓他們買你的書，忘記自己讀過，接著再買一本。

en: Bad news—one of the puppet eyes glued to the journal got crushed against the wall when you threw it. It looks foggy now, like a cataract.
zh: 壞消息：你砸日記本時，粘在封面外殼上的一隻木偶眼睛撞在牆上摔碎了，眼睛裡頭瀰漫著一片霧氣，像是木偶得了白內障。

en: It’s been a couple of days since Jerry’s doctor came to see him, days which he hasn’t gone wandering, days which, as far as he’s aware, he has been mostly in control.
zh: 自從傑瑞的醫生過來探望過他之後，他再也沒有偷偷出去遊盪。據他所知，這幾天風平浪靜，他自控得很好。

en: The daffodils that were in full force in the spring gardens are now limp and wilted. Some rhododendrons are blossoming, others already so heavy with flowers they’re breaking off and landing with a thud on the lawn. Trees are budding in every direction.
zh: 春天時花園裡盛開的水仙花已經凋零枯萎，杜鵑花正怒放，一些開滿花朵的枝丫不堪重負而折斷了，草坪上處處繽紛落英。

en: Jerry knows it’s that time of the year when things happen quickly, that back at his house he’d have gone from mowing the lawns once every two months during winter to once a week during summer.
zh: 樹木萌發出嫩芽，一片勃勃生機的景象。傑瑞知道，每逢這個時節，萬物都在瘋狂而野蠻地生長。他家裡的草地在冬天時每兩個月才修剪一次，而到了夏天每隔一個星期就要修剪一次。

en: At the moment he’s sitting among it, sitting on a bench under a silk tree whose branches are still mostly bare, the sun touching his face.
zh: 此刻他就在一塊草地上，坐在一棵合歡樹下的長椅上。樹木的枝條大多仍是光禿禿的，陽光撫摸著他的臉龐，暖融融的。

en: He’s reading a newspaper, on the front page of which is a woman he recognizes. The woman’s name is Laura Hunt, and Laura was murdered inside her house.
zh: 他正閱讀一份報紙，頭版刊登著一個女人的照片，他記得這個叫勞拉·亨特的女人，她在自己的家中被人殺害了。

en: The article says her body was found Monday. Today, according to the paper, is Thursday.
zh: 新聞上說，她的屍體是星期一被發現的，而這是一份星期四發行的報紙。

en: The article says her body was found in the afternoon.
zh: 新聞上還說，她的屍體是下午被發現的。

en: He remembers hearing that on the radio, and thinking that while he was at the beach enjoying the crisp air this woman was being murdered.
zh: 他記得收音機里曾播報過這則新聞，以為這個女人被害時他正在海灘上呼吸著清新的空氣。

en: He realizes now that he was wrong—her body was found in the afternoon, but the article says she was killed in the morning.
zh: 現在他意識到自己錯了，因為新聞里說她的屍體雖然是在下午被發現的，卻是在早上被害的。

en: Nurse Hamilton is standing in front of him.
zh: 他抬起頭，看見漢密爾頓護士站在他面前。

en: She sits down and puts her hands on his arm. “Jerry?”
zh: 她坐了下來，把手放在他的胳膊上：「傑瑞？」

en: He shakes his head. He’s not okay.
zh: 他搖搖頭，意思是說他並不好。

en: He folds the newspaper in half so he can no longer see the woman’s picture.
zh: 他把報紙對摺起來，這樣他就看不到那個女人的照片了。

en: He is starting to remember.
zh: 他開始回想。

en: “I killed somebody,” he says, and there—the words are in the open for Nurse Hamilton to do with them what she shall.
zh: 「我殺了人。」他說。當這句話脫口而出時，漢密爾頓護士完全可以按自己的方式應對。

en: Call the police would be his bet. He hopes she does. In fact, they might even execute him.
zh: 他打賭她會打電話報警，他也希望她去報警，這樣他們可能會將他處死。

en: The death penalty was abolished over fifty years ago, but with all the violence that’s been happening in New Zealand these past few years people have been asking for its return. There was even a referendum.
zh: 死刑早在五十年前就廢除了，但由於過去這幾年紐西蘭暴力事件頻發，人們一直在呼籲恢復死刑，甚至還進行了全民公投。

en: He remembers it was close, but can’t remember when that was. Last year? Two years ago?
zh: 他記得這事兒就發生在最近，但不記得確切的日子，去年還是兩年前？

en: He also isn’t sure if it’s been put into effect yet, but perhaps he can be the first.
zh: 他並不能確定結果是否已經生效，但他或許可以成為被執行死刑的第一人。

en: If so, he doesn’t want Sandra or Eva there when they hang him. He would like Nurse Hamilton there. He can imagine her sad smile might make things feel a little less scary as the rope gets tightened.
zh: 如果是這樣，當他們絞死他時，他不希望桑德拉或伊娃在場；他希望漢密爾頓護士在場，當她向著他凄然微笑時，在繩索收緊的那一刻他也許會少些恐懼。

en: “I know,” Nurse Hamilton says, a painful expression on her face, and he wonders how she knows, then comes to the conclusion he must have told her already.
zh: 「我知道。」漢密爾頓護士說，臉上浮現出痛苦的神情。他納悶她是怎麼知道的，接著他恍然大悟：一定是自己告訴她的。

en: She carries on. “And I’m sorry, Jerry. I really am, but you do know it wasn’t your fault.”
zh: 她接著說：「我很抱歉，傑瑞，我真的很抱歉，但你知道的，這不是你的錯。」

en: “Of course it was my fault,” he says.
zh: 「當然是我的錯。」

en: “I chose Suzan because I had fallen in love with her.
zh: 他說，「我選擇蘇姍，是因為我愛上了她。

en: I snuck into her house and hurt her and later the police arrested the wrong man.”
zh: 我偷偷潛入她家，殺害了她，後來警方抓錯了人。」

en: Her sorrow melts away. Her concern turns to relief.
zh: 她的悲傷在融化，她的擔憂在消逝。

en: He thinks maybe she didn’t like Suzan.
zh: 他想，也許她並不喜歡蘇姍。

en: “It’s okay,” she says.
zh: 「都會好起來的。」她說。

en: He shakes his head.
zh: 他搖搖頭。

en: It’s never going to be okay.
zh: 永遠都不會好起來的。

en: “Do you remember your name?”
zh: 「你還記得你的名字嗎？」

en: she asks.
zh: 她問。

en: “Of course I remember. It’s Henry Cutter,” he says, but that doesn’t feel quite right.
zh: 「我當然記得，我是亨利·卡特。」

en: “Henry is your pen name,” she says.
zh: 「亨利是你的筆名。」她說。

en: “Pen name?”
zh: 「筆名？」

en: “Jerry Grey is your real name. You’re an author.”
zh: 「傑瑞·格雷才是你的真名，你是個作家。」

en: He searches his memory, trying to form a connection.
zh: 他搜尋著記憶，想重新與過去建立聯繫。

en: “I don’t think so.”
zh: 「我不這麼想。」

en: “You used to write crime novels,” she says.
zh: 「你以前是寫犯罪小說的。」

en: “Sometimes you get confused about what is real and what you made up.
zh: 她說，「有時候你會有些困惑，這是因為你混淆了現實和虛構。

en: Do you know where you are?”
zh: 你知道你在哪裡嗎？」

en: “A nursing home,” he tells her, and as he tells her he starts to look around the grounds, at the trees and flowers, and there are other people here too, people wandering around, some looking happy, some looking sad, some looking lost.
zh: 「療養院。」說著，他開始環顧四周，打量樹木和花草，他還看見那邊四處徘徊的人們，那些歡喜的、憂愁的、迷惘的人。

en: He is, he remembers, and somewhat ironically too, he thinks, one of the lost.
zh: 有點兒諷刺的是，他想起他自己也是屬於那一部分迷惘的人的。

en: “I have dementia.”
zh: 「我有老年痴呆症。」

en: “The dementia has an awful way of rewriting your past, Jerry. It’s making the stories from your novels feel like real life to you.
zh: 「老年痴呆症會改寫你過去的記憶，傑瑞，所以會讓你覺得小說中的故事像是真實發生過的。

en: Suzan doesn’t exist. She never existed.”
zh: 沒有什麼蘇姍，她根本不存在。」

en: He thinks about that. Writing books . . . it does feel familiar.
zh: 他苦苦思索著，寫作……這倒不覺得陌生了。

en: And of course his name is Jerry Grey. Not Henry Cutter.
zh: 還有，他的名字是傑瑞·格雷，而不是亨利·卡特。

en: Henry Cutter is who he would become when he wrote, because that way he could be Henry for the bad times and Jerry for the good.
zh: 亨利·卡特是他寫書時才用的名字，因為構建驚悚場景的是亨利，享受美好生活的卻是傑瑞。

en: “So I didn’t kill anybody,” he says.
zh: 「所以，我沒有殺任何人，對嗎？」他說。

en: Nurse Hamilton gives him one of the saddest smiles he’s ever seen, the kind of smile that makes his chest tighten. This woman pities him.
zh: 漢密爾頓護士沖他憂傷地一笑，這是他所見過的最為憂傷的笑容，讓他感覺胸口一陣一陣發緊。

en: “There was no Suzan,” she says. “She was just a figment of your imagination.”
zh: 「沒有什麼蘇姍，」她說，「蘇姍只是你臆造、虛構出來的人物。」

en: “But she seems . . seems so real.”
zh: 「但她似乎……似乎是那麼真實。」

en: “I know.
zh: 「我知道。

en: Come on, let’s get you inside.
zh: 好了，我們進去吧。

en: It’s almost dinnertime.”
zh: 快要吃晚飯了。」

en: She leads him inside and he tells her he wants to rest for a bit in his room. She walks him there, and tells him everything is going to be okay, then tells him not to be too long.
zh: 她把他帶進去，他說他想在房間休息一下，她便陪著他走進房間，告訴他一切都會好起來的，隨後又說不要待得太長。

en: It’s not until he’s in his room and alone and sitting by the window that he thinks back over the conversation and picks up on what he missed.
zh: 他獨自待在自己的房間里，坐在窗邊，這時他開始回味剛才那段對話，察覺到剛剛沒有察覺到的破綻。

en: “So I didn’t kill anybody.
zh: 「我知道。」她說。「所以，我並沒有殺任何人，是嗎？

en: That’s what I asked you,” he says, the words going into an empty room—empty except for Forgetful Jerry, and Forgetful Jerry doesn’t seem to mind him talking to himself.
zh: 這才是我想要問你的。」他說，這句話在空蕩蕩的房間里來回飄蕩，除了健忘的傑瑞，這房裡再無他人，但他好像並不介意自言自語。

en: When he talks again, he looks at the empty chair opposite as if Nurse Hamilton was there.
zh: 他再開口說話時，盯著對面的空椅子，彷彿漢密爾頓護士就坐在那裡。

en: “Then you said I didn’t kill Suzan. You didn’t say I didn’t kill anybody.”
zh: 「你說我沒殺死蘇姍，但你沒有說我沒有殺死過別人。」

en: He replays the conversation over again.
zh: 他把那個對話又重複了一遍。

en: He didn’t kill Suzan.
zh: 他沒有殺死蘇姍。

en: You killed somebody.
zh: 「但你殺了其他人。」

en: The words aren’t his, but he knows who they belong to.
zh: 說話的不是他，但他知道是誰說的。

en: Henry Cutter, his pen name, wants to be heard.
zh: 是亨利·卡特，這個冠以他筆名的人想讓他聽到自己的聲音。

en: You killed somebody, and Nurse Hamilton knew.
zh: 「你殺了其他人，而且漢密爾頓護士知道。」

en: But if it wasn’t Suzan, then just who in the hell was it?
zh: 但是，如果不是蘇姍，那麼他究竟又殺了誰呢？
